title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for a reasonable setup that would allow useful measurements

1 point is earned for indicating all the measurements needed to determine the velocities

1 point is earned for having no obviously extraneous equipment or measurements

Examples:

  • Use tape to mark off two distances on the track — one for cart A before the collision and one for the combined carts after the collision. Push cart A to give it an initial speed. Use a stopwatch to measure the time it takes for the cart(s) to cross the marked distances. The speeds are the distances divided by the times.

  • Place a motion detector at the left end of the track. Push cart A to give it an initial speed. Record position as a function of time, first for cart A and then for the combined carts A and B.
descriptions:

1 point is earned for a reasonable setup that would allow useful measurements

1 point is earned for indicating all the measurements needed to determine the velocities

1 point is earned for having no obviously extraneous equipment or measurements

Examples:

Use a stopwatch to measure the time it takes for the cart(s) to cross the marked distances. The speeds are the distances divided by the times.

  • Place a motion detector at the left end of the track. Push cart A to give it an initial speed. Record position as a function of time, first for cart A and then for the combined carts A and B.

The student response earns one of the following points:

1 point is earned for indicating all the measurements needed to determine the velocities

1 point is earned for having no obviously extraneous equipment or measurements

Examples:

Use a stopwatch to measure the time it takes for the cart(s) to cross the marked distances. The speeds are the distances divided by the times.

  • Place a motion detector at the left end of the track. Push cart A to give it an initial speed. Record position as a function of time, first for cart A and then for the combined carts A and B.

The student response earns two of the following points:

1 point is earned for a reasonable setup that would allow useful measurements

1 point is earned for indicating all the measurements needed to determine the velocities

1 point is earned for having no obviously extraneous equipment or measurements

Examples:

Use a stopwatch to measure the time it takes for the cart(s) to cross the marked distances. The speeds are the distances divided by the times.

  • Place a motion detector at the left end of the track. Push cart A to give it an initial speed. Record position as a function of time, first for cart A and then for the combined carts A and B.

The student response earns all of the following points:

1 point is earned for a reasonable setup that would allow useful measurements

1 point is earned for indicating all the measurements needed to determine the velocities

1 point is earned for having no obviously extraneous equipment or measurements

Examples:

  • Use tape to mark off two distances on the track — one for cart A before the collision and one for the combined carts after the collision. Push cart A to give it an initial speed. Use a stopwatch to measure the time it takes for the cart(s) to cross the marked distances. The speeds are the distances divided by the times.

  • Place a motion detector at the left end of the track. Push cart A to give it an initial speed. Record position as a function of time, first for cart A and then for the combined carts A and B.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for indicating a reasonable assumption about the relative size of the measurement errors before and after the collision

1 point is earned for correctly using the assumption in comparing the effect on the calculated value of the mass of cart B

Example:

If the measurement errors are of the same magnitude, they will have a greater effect after the collision. The speed of the combined carts will be less than the initial speed of cart A, so errors of the same magnitude will be a greater percentage of the actual value after the collision. So the values after the collision will have a greater effect on the value of the mass of cart B.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for providing sufficient description of the principles used in t he calculation (in either a single explanation or dispersed throughout the calculations)

Conservation of momentum can be used to determine the mass of cart B: mAvi = (mA + mB)vf

1 point is earned for correctly recognizing the two regions on the graph corresponding to before and after the collision

1 point is earned for using data from the graph to attempt calculation of speed from slope

1 point is earned for indicating use of the slope of one or two drawn lines to determine one or more speeds (This point cannot be earned if calculations use data points not on the line[s].)

The speed vi before the collision is the slope of the best-fit line for the data from 0 to 1 s.

The speed vf after the collision is the slope of the best-fit line for the data from 1 s to 2 s.

Using the example lines drawn above:

v i = ( 1.4−0 )m ( 0.9−0 )s = 14 9 m s v f = ( 2.1−1.5 )m ( 1.9−1.0 )s = 0.6m 0.9s = 2 3 m s MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGceaqabeaacaWG2b WaaSbaaSqaaiaadMgaaeqaaOGaeyypa0ZaaSaaaeaadaqadaqaaiaa igdacaGGUaGaaGinaiabgkHiTiaaicdaaiaawIcacaGLPaaacaWGTb aabaWaaeWaaeaacaaIWaGaaiOlaiaaiMdacqGHsislcaaIWaaacaGL OaGaayzkaaGaam4CaaaacqGH9aqpdaWcaaqaaiaaigdacaaI0aaaba GaaGyoaaaadaWcaaqaaiaad2gaaeaacaWGZbaaaaqaaiaadAhadaWg aaWcbaGaamOzaaqabaGccqGH9aqpdaWcaaqaamaabmaabaGaaGOmai aac6cacaaIXaGaeyOeI0IaaGymaiaac6cacaaI1aaacaGLOaGaayzk aaGaamyBaaqaamaabmaabaGaaGymaiaac6cacaaI5aGaeyOeI0IaaG ymaiaac6cacaaIWaaacaGLOaGaayzkaaGaam4CaaaacqGH9aqpdaWc aaqaaiaaicdacaGGUaGaaGOnaiaad2gaaeaacaaIWaGaaiOlaiaaiM dacaWGZbaaaiabg2da9maalaaabaGaaGOmaaqaaiaaiodaaaWaaSaa aeaacaWGTbaabaGaam4Caaaaaaaa@69BA@

The student response earns three of the following points:

1 point is earned for providing sufficient description of the principles used in t he calculation (in either a single explanation or dispersed throughout the calculations)

Conservation of momentum can be used to determine the mass of cart B: mAvi = (mA + mB)vf

1 point is earned for correctly recognizing the two regions on the graph corresponding to before and after the collision

1 point is earned for using data from the graph to attempt calculation of speed from slope

1 point is earned for indicating use of the slope of one or two drawn lines to determine one or more speeds (This point cannot be earned if calculations use data points not on the line[s].)

The speed vi before the collision is the slope of the best-fit line for the data from 0 to 1 s.

The speed vf after the collision is the slope of the best-fit line for the data from 1 s to 2 s.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for an answer consistent with previous responses that indicates a modification of the procedure to accomplish varying the initial speed of cart A or one of the cart masses OR that indicates that the previously described procedure would provide appropriate data, so it does not need modification

1 point is earned for indicating that the data can be used to calculate the kinetic energy K before and after the collision

1 point is earned for indicating that the fraction of K lost in the various collisions should be compared

Example:

You could vary the initial speed of cart A. From the data, calculate values of kinetic energy before and after the collision using K = (1/2)mv2. Then analyze ((Ki - Kf)/Ki) to see if the changes in initial speed give different values.
descriptions:
The student response earns none of the following points:

1 point is earned for an answer consistent with previous responses that indicates a modification of the procedure to accomplish varying the initial speed of cart A or one of the cart masses OR that indicates that the previously described procedure would provide appropriate data, so it does not need modification

1 point is earned for indicating that the data can be used to calculate the kinetic energy K before and after the collision

1 point is earned for indicating that the fraction of K lost in the various collisions should be compared

Example:

You could vary the initial speed of cart A. From the data, calculate values of kinetic energy before and after the collision using K = (1/2)mv2. Then analyze ((Ki - Kf)/Ki) to see if the changes in initial speed give different values.

The student response earns one of the following points:

1 point is earned for indicating that the data can be used to calculate the kinetic energy K before and after the collision

1 point is earned for indicating that the fraction of K lost in the various collisions should be compared

Example:

You could vary the initial speed of cart A. From the data, calculate values of kinetic energy before and after the collision using K = (1/2)mv2. Then analyze ((Ki - Kf)/Ki) to see if the changes in initial speed give different values.

1 point is earned for indicating that the fraction of K lost in the various collisions should be compared
